title: The Wall Street Journal: White House says Trump still has ‘full faith’ in Kelly
text:
4:15 p.m. ET Share 
Top officials deny chief of staff may be on the way out Reuters White House chief of staff John Kelly is under fire for his handling of Rob Porter. 
By Rebecca Ballhaus 
WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump has full confidence in John Kelly, White House officials said Sunday, after the president in recent days had privately criticized his chief of staff’s handling of domestic-abuse allegations against a senior aide. 
Top officials also defended Trump’s recent public statements about abuse, in which he emphasized that many people’s lives were “shattered” by accusations of abuse, but didn’t express concern for the victims of the abuse. White House adviser Kellyanne Conway said Trump’s view is that his chief of staff is “doing a great job and that he has full faith in him.” 
“I spoke to the president last night,” Conway said in an interview on CNN with Jake Tapper. “He said, ‘please tell Jake that I have full faith in chief of staff John Kelly and that I’m not actively searching for replacements.’ ” 
On NBC, White House legislative affairs director Marc Short said the president has “absolute confidence” in Kelly. Short also disputed reports that Kelly had told the president he was willing to resign over his handling of the allegations against Rob Porter, the White House staff secretary who resigned last week after two reports of allegedly abusive behavior toward his ex-wives.
